question: Question_01_(g)
statement: Find the interval(s) on which $f(x) = x + \frac1x$ is increasing.
sols:
Taking the derivative of this function yields

$\displaystyle f'(x) = 1 -\frac{1}{x^{2}}$

The derivative is undefined at \emph{x} = 0 (as is the original
function) and setting the derivative to 0 also gives

\begin{align*} \frac{1}{x^{2}} &= 1 \\ x &= \pm 1 \end{align*}

Thus $\displaystyle f$ has three critical points and four intervals to
check:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  On $\displaystyle (-\infty, -1)$ the derivative is positive and the
  function is increasing.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  On $\displaystyle (-1,0)$ the derivative is negative and the function
  is decreasing.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  On $\displaystyle (0,1)$ the derivative is negative and the function
  is decreasing.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  On $\displaystyle (1,\infty)$ the derivative is positive and the
  function is increasing.
\end{itemize}

Therefore the function is increasing on
${\color{blue} \displaystyle (-\infty,-1) \cup(1,\infty)}$.
hints:
To find the intervals of increase and decrease of $\displaystyle f$, we
need to check the sign of $\displaystyle f'$ between \textbf{critical
points} (i.e., where $\displaystyle f'$ is undefined or is equal to
zero).
